title.title: Malaria Threats Map
title.subtitle: Tracking biological challenges to malaria control and elimination

dataSection.title: Where do the data come from?
dataSection.content: Data are collected by National Malaria Programmes, their implementation partners, research institutes and non-governmental organizations. They are either provided directly to WHO Global Malaria Programme (GMP) or extracted from publications. All data are quality controlled, incorporated into WHO global databases and then published to the Malaria Threats Map.

mapSection.title: Watch: Find out about the functionality of the maps within the MTM

video3.title: How is the MTM supporting countries?

challengesSection.title: Thousands of people use the Malaria Threats Map to understand challenges to malaria control and elimination, access data and guide decision-making.

tab1.name: National Malaria Control Programmes
tab1.text: The MTM gives me access to the most recent public data on vector insecticide resistance – this helps me make decisions around which insecticide products to fund for IRS and whether standard LLINs or new Pyrethroid-PBO nets should be deployed. The interactivity of the platform allows me to select the specific criteria that I am interested in – and then easily export visualisations to facilitate discussions. No other platform is as comprehensive as the MTM.

userExperienceSection.title: User experience testing
userExperienceSection.p1: We have recently undertaken a process of user experience testing and are grateful to all who willingly gave of their time to contribute to the improvement of the MTM for all its users.
userExperienceSection.p2: This user testing has led to the addition of the home, about and contact pages, the creation of the dashboards, a dedicated download interface, and a more streamlined map interface. We have also identified additional areas of improvement, which we are working on. These include increased guidance to facilitate decision-making, and additional map layers. We want to make this tool the best it can be so that together we have the resources to control and eliminate malaria.

filtersSection.note: Note: A large number of data points are needed to create a dashboard. For this reason, dashboards are currently only available for two of the four themes: vector insecticide resistance and antimalarial drug efficacy and resistance. Dashboards will continue to develop as more data becomes available.

common.studyProtocol: Study protocol: WHO recommends that all therapeutic efficacy studies are conducted according to the WHO standard protocol.
common.info: To view more details about a specific study, return to the map interface to view the site-level data.

summaryTreatmentFailureRateByDrug.chartInterpretation: Chart interpretation: This bar chart shows the number of therapeutic efficacy studies conducted in a selected country (or countries). The user can customize the chart by selecting one Plasmodium species, as well as selecting one or more drugs, and year(s) of interest. The user can also exclude studies with less than 20 patients from the chart. Studies with >10% of patients with treatment failure are shown in red; studies with {{lessThen}}10% of patients with treatment failure are shown in pink.
summaryTreatmentFailureRateByDrug.dataAvailability: Data availability: All studies for which data are available are shown.

treatmentFailureRateOverTime.chartInterpretation: Chart interpretation: This scatter plot displays the percentage of patients with treatment failure, in a therapeutic efficacy study conducted in a selected country (or countries), by year. The user can customize the chart by selecting a Plasmodium species, a drug, and the years of interest. The user can also exclude studies with less than 20 patients from the chart.
treatmentFailureRateOverTime.description_1: Each circle represents one therapeutic efficacy study. The size of the circle is indicative of the total number of patients included in the study. The colour of the circle indicates the country where the study was conducted.
treatmentFailureRateOverTime.description_2: The placement of the circles along the x-axis is based on the year in which the study was completed. There is a slight horizontal displacement of the circles, within a year interval, in order to reduce the appearance of overlapping circles.
treatmentFailureRateOverTime.dataAvailability: Data availability: Only data for P. falciparum and P. vivax are displayed in this graph.

parasiteClearanceRatesOverTime.chartInterpretation: Chart interpretation: This scatter plot displays the percentage of patients with delayed parasite clearance, in a therapeutic efficacy study, conducted in a selected country (or countries), by year. The user can customize the chart by selecting a Plasmodium species, a drug, and the years of interest. The user can also exclude studies with less than 20 patients from the chart.
parasiteClearanceRatesOverTime.description_1: Each circle represents one therapeutic efficacy study. The size of the circle is indicative of the total number of patients included in the study. The colour of the circle indicates the country where the study was conducted.
parasiteClearanceRatesOverTime.description_2: The placement of the circles along the x-axis is based on the year in which the study was completed. There is slight horizontal displacement of the circles, within a year interval, in order to reduce overlapping circles.
parasiteClearanceRatesOverTime.dataAvailability: Data availability: Only data for P. falciparum and P. vivax are displayed in this graph.

summaryMolecularMarkerStudyOverTime.intro: Molecular marker studies identify and track the prevalence of molecular mutations associated with antimalarial drug resistance. The user can customize the chart by selecting the type of molecular marker study and the years of interest. The user can also exclude studies with less than 20 patients from the chart.
summaryMolecularMarkerStudyOverTime.chartInterpretation: Chart interpretation: This stacked bar chart displays the molecular marker study results. The height of the bar is determined by the number of studies conducted in that year.

pfkelch13.description: The colour of the bar represents the percentage of samples within one study where validated and candidate molecular markers were detected. Light blue indicates a low percentage; dark blue represents a high percentage.
pfkelch13.list_1: Validated markers include: (F466I, N458Y, Y493H, R539T, I543T, P553L, R561H, P574L, C580Y)
pfkelch13.list_2: Associated /candidate markers include: (P441L, G449A, C469F/Y, A481V, R515K, P527H, N5371/D, G538V, V568G, R6221, A675V)

summaryMolecularMarkerStudyOverTime.pfcrt: The colour of the bar represents the percentage of samples within one study where mutations were detected. Light blue indicates a low percentage; dark blue represents a high percentage.
summaryMolecularMarkerStudyOverTime.pfmdr1: The colour of the bar represents the percentage of samples within one study where multiple copy numbers were detected. Light blue indicates a low percentage; dark blue represents a high percentage.
summaryMolecularMarkerStudyOverTime.dataAvailability: Data availability: All studies for which data are available are shown.

homepage.header: The Malaria Threats Map is the most comprehensive platform on the four biological threats to malaria control and elimination.

theme_paper.prevention_subtitle: Vector resistance to the insecticides used for vector control  threatens malaria control efforts.
theme_paper.invasive_subtitle: The spread of certain anopheline vector species and their establishment in new ecosystems poses a threat to malaria control.
theme_paper.treatment_subtitle: Antimalarial drug resistance remains one of the key threats to global malaria control efforts, particularly in the Greater Mekong Subregion.
theme_paper.diagnosis_subtitle: Gene deletions among some malaria parasites cause false negative diagnostic test results, complicating case management and control.

shareDataPage.title: Contribute to the Malaria Threats Map by sharing your data

section1.title: Contribute insecticide resistance data
section1.description: We invite data submissions from all individuals and organizations. Please report your data using the following WHO standard data collection forms. Forms are available for download <2 href='https://www.who.int/teams/global-malaria-programme/prevention/vector-control/global-database-on-insecticide-resistance-in-malaria-vectors'>here</2>.

section2.title: Contribute An. stephensi detection data
section2.description: We invite data submissions from all individuals and organizations about An. stephensi detection outside of its native areas. Please report your data using the WHO standard data collection form, available <5 href='https://www.who.int/teams/global-malaria-programme/prevention/vector-control/global-database-on-insecticide-resistance-in-malaria-vectors'>here.

shareDataPage.sectionsFooter: Completed forms can be sent to: <2>vectorsurveillance@who.int</2>

cards.prevention: Resistance of malaria mosquitoes to insecticides used in core prevention tools of treated bed nets and indoor residual sprays threatens vector control effectiveness

cards.invasive: The spread of anopheline mosquito vector species and their establishment in ecosystems to which they are not native poses a potential threat to the control and elimination of malaria

help.p1: This map contains data from <1>intensity concentration bioassays</1>. Each dot on the map represents a study site containing one or more studies. In sites where studies show varying levels of resistance intensity, the colour of the dot is determined by the most recent results.
help.p2: For information on how each level is defined, please consult the <1 href='/'>WHO manual for resistance monitoring</1>.
help.footer: Data source: Publications and unpublished reports and information from country offices.

help.p1: This map contains data from <1>discriminating concentration bioassays</1>. Each dot on the map represents a study site containing one or more studies. In sites where studies show varying levels of resistance intensity, the colour of the dot is determined by the most recent results.
help.p2: For information on how each level is defined, please consult the <1 href='/'>WHO manual for resistance monitoring</1>.
help.footer: Data source: Publications and unpublished reports and information from country offices.

help.p1: This map contains data from <1>molecular assays, biochemical assays and synergist-insecticide bioassays</1>. Each dot on the map represents a study site containing one or more studies. The colour of the dot shows whether or not a molecular marker associated with insecticide resistance has been detected in mosquitoes collected on the site. The colour of the dot is determined by the most recent results.
help.footer: Data source: Publications and unpublished reports and information from country offices.

help.p1: This map presents data from <1>synergist-insecticide bioassays</1>. Each dot on the map represents a study site containing one or more studies. In sites where studies show varying results, the colour of the dot is determined by the most recent results.
help.p2: For information on how synergist involvement is graded consult the <1 href='/'>WHO manual for resistance monitoring</1>.
help.footer: Data source: Publications and unpublished reports and information from country offices.

terms_step.title: Terms and Conditions
terms_step.p1: The use of all data is subject to the Terms and conditions of use for WHO compilations, aggregations, evaluations and analyses. By using the Datasets or any presentations of data derived from them, you agree to be bound by and adhere to these Terms and Conditions, as may be amended from time to time by WHO at its sole discretion. If any datasets are credited to a source other than WHO, then those materials are not covered by these Terms and Conditions, and permission should be sought from the source.
terms_step.p2: Please acknowledge the use of these datasets by including the following reference in your publications: WHO, Malaria Threats Map, year, date of access, acknowledgement of the countries having provided the underlying data (in the event that the source refers to ministries of health or national malaria control programs of specific countries).
terms_step.check: Check here to indicated that you have read and agree to the Terms and Conditions of use for WHO data compilations, aggregations, evaluations and analyses.

personal_step.title: Personal details
personal_step.uses_placeHolder: We are interested in knowing what you are using the data for. We would appreciate if you could provide a short description.
personal_step.message: WHO is keen to improve the global databases and Malaria Threats Map to better serve the needs of our user community. Hence, WHO would like to engage with our user community to collect suggestions for improvement and to learn from different use cases and benefits that these products bring to them. If you would like to share feedback, you can do so <1 href='/contact'>here</1>.
personal_step.consent1: I consent to be contacted by the World Health Organization regarding my experience using the Malaria Threats Map and data from the global databases.
personal_step.consent2: I consent for the World Health Organization to use my organization name and project description provided above to showcase the use of the global databases (no personal data will be shown).

data_step.title: Select data
data_step.p1: This dialogue allows you to download data from four of the WHO global databases: insecticide resistance in malaria vectors, invasive vector species, antimalarial drug efficacy and resistance, and <1>pfhrp2/3</1> gene deletions. A link to the original data source and citation are included in each dataset, where available.
data_step.last_updated: The selected dataset was last updated on:
data_step.db_download_helper_text: Your list of databases selected for download will be shown here. To add data, please filter for the data you require on the right and click “Add to download”.
data_step.prevention_warning: Please note that not every contributor of the vector insecticide resistance theme has allowed us to share their data. Hence some of the data in Malaria Threats Map is not available for download. For data extracted from publications, please note that when the values of relevant variables were not directly provided in the publications or were analyzed differently than recommended by WHO, values were calculated from the reported data.

step1.part1: <0>Gene deletions among malaria parasites causes false-negative diagnostic test results</0>
step1.part2: Rapid diagnostic tests (RDT) are used for malaria diagnosis in most endemic areas. Detection of Plasmodium falciparum - the most deadly malaria parasite globally - relies heavily on RDTs that target an antigen called histidine-rich protein 2 (HRP2), as well as some cross-reactivity with HRP3, a structurally similar parasite protein. The vast majority of RDTs manufactured, procured and used around the world are based on detection of HRP2 either alone or in combination with other antigens (such as parasite lactate dehydrogenase or aldolase).
step1.part3: However, in 2010 a study sponsored by WHO and FIND found that some P. falciparum parasites in Peru lacked the pfhrp2 gene. Without this gene, the parasite cannot produce HRP2 and cannot be detected by HRP2-based RDTs. This was the first report to confirm the absence of the pfhrp2 gene among P. falciparum parasites in a clinical setting.
step1.part4: Gamboa et al. (2010) A large proportion of P. falciparum isolates in the Amazon region of Peru lack pfhrp2 and pfhrp3: implications for malaria rapid diagnostic tests. PLoS One. 5(1):e8091

step2.part1: <0> pfhrp2/3 gene deletions may have significant implications for public health
step2.part2: False negative RDT results due to pfhrp2/3 deletions can lead to incorrect or delayed diagnosis and threaten patient safety. The patient may also continue to be a source of malaria transmission until properly treated.
step2.part3: Since 2010, surveys in several settings in Africa and Asia have also found a varying proportion of P. falciparum parasites lacking the pfhrp2 gene. The prevalence of this genetic mutation reportedly varies between and within countries. If confirmed, RDT procurement and case management practices need to be tailored accordingly. WHO recommends a change to an RDT that is not exclusively based on HRP2 for P. falciparum detection (ie. pf-pLDH) if the prevalence of false negative RDTs due to pfhrp2 deletion is ≥ 5% amongst symptomatic patients.

step3.part1: <0>Increased monitoring of P. falciparum populations for pfhrp2/3 gene deletions is essential
step3.part2: Once pfhrp2/3 deletions are confirmed in a geographical region, surveys should be conducted locally and in neighbouring areas to estimate the prevalence of the parasites carrying gene deletions. In clinical settings the cause(s) of false negative RDTs should be investigated.
step3.part3: Sentinel surveillance should be instituted with all findings (positive and negative) reported. Data must be managed well to help prioritize surveys, adequately monitoring trends over time, and to inform a coordinated response.
step3.part4: As of 2018, the WHO database includes pfhrp2/3 gene deletion data for 29 countries across five WHO regions

disclaimer.p1b: Map production: Global Malaria Programme. World Health Organization.
disclaimer.p2: Unless otherwise specifically stated, the information contained in this application has been made available to the World Health Organization (WHO) Global Malaria Programme by Ministries of Health or their development partners, or through extraction by WHO or contracted partners from publications in international peer-reviewed scientific journals. WHO therefore provides no assurance as to the validity, accuracy or completeness of this information.
disclaimer.p3a: The use of all images and files generated from this application is subject to the
disclaimer.p3b: Terms and Conditions of use for WHO data compilations, aggregations, evaluations and analyses.
disclaimer.p4a: The following citation shall be conspicuously provided alongside images or files generated from the application.

disclaimerTab.name: Disclaimer
disclaimerTab.disclaimer: The use of all data is subject to the Terms and Conditions of use for WHO data compilations, aggregations, evaluations and analyses. By using the Datasets or any presentations of data derived from them, you agree to be bound by and adhere to these Terms and Conditions, as may be amended from time to time by WHO at its sole discretion. If any datasets are credited to a source other than WHO, then those materials are not covered by these Terms and Conditions, and permission should be sought from the source. Please acknowledge the use of these datasets by including the following reference in your publications: WHO, Malaria Threats Map, year, date of access, acknowledgement of the countries having provided the underlying data (in the event that the source refers to ministries of health or national malaria control programs of specific countries). Please note that not every contributor has allowed us to share their data. Hence some of the data in Malaria Threats Map is not available for download. For data extracted from publications, please note that when the values of relevant variables were not directly provided in the publications or were analyzed differently than recommended by WHO, values were calculated from the reported data. WHO has made a best effort to geolocate all the studies for which coordinate were not provided or wrong coordinates were provided. However, precise coordinates could not always be found. Hence the coordinates  provided in this datasets often correspond to the closest location that could be found, i.e the center of the village or district.

invasive.ID: Unique identifier of the mosquito collection that lead to the identification of the species
invasive.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the mosquitoes were collected
invasive.SITE_NAME: Site where the mosquitoes were collected
invasive.LATITUDE: Latitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
invasive.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
invasive.STAGE: Life stage of the colleted mosquitoes
invasive.YEAR_START: Life stage of the colleted mosquitoes
invasive.MONTH_START: Month when the mosquito collection started
invasive.YEAR_END: Year when the mosquito collection ended
invasive.MONTH_END: Month when the mosquito collection ended
invasive.SAMPLING_METHOD: Sampling method used to collect the mosquitoes
invasive.BREEDING_HABITAT: Breeding habitat where the mosquitos were collected
invasive.ID_METHOD: Method used to identify the species of the mosquitoes
invasive.DATA_SOURCE:
Institution or group that collected the data. 
Note: In the event that the data was extracted from a publication, this variable will saw "Extracted from publication"
invasive.CITATION: Citation of the publication where the data was published
invasive.CITATION_URL: URL of the publication where the data was published
invasive.DATA_CURATOR: Institute that compiled the data. Part of the data in this databases has been compiled by WHO's partner institutions and submited to or shared with WHO.This column will indicate the name of the institution or group that compiled the data.
invasive.INVASIVE_STATUS:
This variable indicates whether the mosquitoes collected are considered invasive or native. 
Note: An invasive species  is a non-native species that establishes in a new ecosystem, and causes, or has the potential to cause, harm to the environment, economy, or human health

mm.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the study was conducted
mm.SITE_NAME: Site where the study was conducted
mm.ADMIN2: Administrative level 2 where the study was conducted
mm.LATITUDE: Latitude of the site where the study was conducted
mm.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the study was conducted
mm.DRUG_NAME:
Treatment administered to patients during the study.
Note: only shown if the data comes from a Therapeutic efficacy study.
mm.DATA_SOURCE: Institution or group that conducted the study or survey
mm.CITATION_URL: URL of the publication where the data was published
mm.PROPORTION: Percentage of the samples with the genotype

therapeutic_efficacy.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the study was conducted
therapeutic_efficacy.ADMIN2: Administrative level 2 where the study was conducted

therapeutic_efficacy.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the study was conducted
therapeutic_efficacy.DRUG_NAME:
Treatment administered to patients during the study.
Note: only shown if the data comes from a Therapeutic efficacy study.
therapeutic_efficacy.SAMPLE_SIZE: Number of patients that completed the study (i.e. that were not lost to follow-up or withdrawn)
therapeutic_efficacy.FOLLOW_UP: Number of days that patients are followed-up
therapeutic_efficacy.POSITIVE_DAY_3: Percentage of parasite positive patients on day 3
therapeutic_efficacy.TREATMENT_FAILURE_PP: Percentage of patients with treatment failure
therapeutic_efficacy.TREATMENT_FAILURE_KM: Estimated percentage of patients with treatment failure at the end of the follow up period based on Kaplan Meier curves
therapeutic_efficacy.DATA_SOURCE: Institution or group that conducted the study
therapeutic_efficacy.CITATION_URL: URL of the publication where the data was published

biochemical_assay.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the bioassay was conducted
biochemical_assay.ADMIN1: Administrative level 1 where the mosquitoes where collected
biochemical_assay.ADMIN2: Administrative level 2 where the mosquitoes where collected
biochemical_assay.SITE_NAME: Site where the mosquitoes were collected
biochemical_assay.SITE_CODE: Code of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
biochemical_assay.LATITUDE: Latitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
biochemical_assay.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
biochemical_assay.YEAR_START: Year when the mosquito collection started
biochemical_assay.VECTOR_SPECIES: Species of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide
biochemical_assay.STAGE_ORIGIN: Life stage and origin of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
biochemical_assay.MOSQUITO_NUMBER: Total number of mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
biochemical_assay.MECHANISM_STATUS: State of detection of the resistance mechanism that the test aimed to indetify
biochemical_assay.DATA_SOURCE:
Institution or group that collected the data. 
Note: In the event that the data was extracted from a publication, this variable will saw "Extracted from publication"
biochemical_assay.CITATION: Citation of the publication where the data was published
biochemical_assay.CITATION_URL: URL of the publication where the data was published
biochemical_assay.DATA_CURATOR: Institute that compiled the data. Part of the data in this databases has been compiled by WHO's partner institutions and submited to or shared with WHO.This column will indicate the name of the institution or group that compiled the data.

molecular_assay.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the bioassay was conducted
molecular_assay.ADMIN1: Administrative level 1 where the mosquitoes where collected
molecular_assay.ADMIN2: Administrative level 2 where the mosquitoes where collected
molecular_assay.SITE_NAME: Site where the mosquitoes were collected
molecular_assay.SITE_CODE: Code of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
molecular_assay.LATITUDE: Latitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
molecular_assay.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
molecular_assay.YEAR_START: Year when the mosquito collection started
molecular_assay.VECTOR_SPECIES: Species of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide
molecular_assay.STAGE_ORIGIN: Life stage and origin of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
molecular_assay.MOSQUITO_NUMBER: Total number of mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
molecular_assay.MECHANISM_STATUS: State of detection of the resistance mechanism that the test aimed to indetify
molecular_assay.DATA_SOURCE:
Institution or group that collected the data. 
Note: In the event that the data was extracted from a publication, this variable will saw "Extracted from publication"

synergist.COUNTRY_NAME: Name of the country where the bioassay was conducted
synergist.ADMIN1: Administrative level 1 where the mosquitoes where collected
synergist.ADMIN2: Administrative level 2 where the mosquitoes where collected
synergist.SITE_NAME: Site where the mosquitoes were collected
synergist.SITE_CODE: Code of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
synergist.LATITUDE: Latitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
synergist.LONGITUDE: Longitude of the site where the mosquitoes were collected
synergist.YEAR_START: Year when the mosquito collection started
synergist.VECTOR_SPECIES: Species of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide
synergist.STAGE_ORIGIN: Life stage and origin of the mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
synergist.MOSQUITO_NUMBER: Total number of mosquitoes exposed to insecticide during the bioassay
synergist.TIME_HOLDING_POSTEXPOSURE: Time during which mosquitoes were maintained in holding tubes after exposure
synergist.MORTALITY_ADJUSTED_SYNERGIST_INSECTICIDE: Adjusted mortality among mosquitoes exposed to synergist and insecticide. When the control mortality is between 5% and 20% this variable shows the results of applying Abbott's formula to the average observed mosquito mortality accross all replicates. When control mortaliy was below 5%, this variable shows the average observed mosquito mortality across all replicates.
synergist.MORTALITY_ADJUSTED_INSECTICIDE_ONLY: Adjusted mortality among mosquitoes exposed to insecticide only. When the control mortality is between 5% and 20% this variable shows the results of applying Abbott's formula to the average observed mosquito mortality accross all replicates. When control mortaliy was below 5%, this variable shows the average observed mosquito mortality across all replicates.
synergist.METABOLIC_MECHANISM_INVOLVEMENT: Level of involvement of metabolic mechanism
synergist.DATA_SOURCE:
Institution or group that collected the data. 
Note: In the event that the data was extracted from a publication, this variable will saw "Extracted from publication"
synergist.CITATION: Citation of the publication where the data was published
synergist.CITATION_URL: URL of the publication where the data was published
synergist.DATA_CURATOR: Institute that compiled the data. Part of the data in this databases has been compiled by WHO's partner institutions and submited to or shared with WHO.This column will indicate the name of the institution or group that compiled the data.

step1.part1: <0>The recent detection of An. stephensi in Sri Lanka and the horn of Africa underscores the potential for vector species to spread and establish in new geographical areas.
step1.part2: <0>An. Gambiae’s invasion of northern Brazil in 1930 provides another example. Its elimination between 1930s and early 40s proves that vector invasions can be controlled.
step1.part3: An. stephensi is a highly efficient urban malaria vector traditionally reported from certain countries in South-East Asia and the Arabian Peninsula. Since 2012, it has been detected in Djibouti (2012), Ethiopia (2016), Sri Lanka (2017) and most recently in the Republic of the Sudan (2019, unpublished report).
step1.part4: The invasion of An. stephensi has contributed to the resurgence of malaria in Djibouti City. In Sri Lanka, the recent invasion of this vector could jeopardize efforts to prevent the re-establishment of malaria. In Africa, given the rapid and uncontrolled growth of cities, further spread and establishment of An. stephensi in urban environments could put at risk the gains in malaria burden reduction made since 2000.

step2.part1: <0>Timely detection of invasive vector species is crucial to contain their spread.</0>
step2.part2: <0>Entomological surveillance systems provide critical information to inform the design and implementation of vector control strategies.</0>
step2.part3: Understanding vector species’ breeding and resting habitats, behaviour, feeding preferences and resistance status is required to design effective interventions to prevent further spread of invasive vector species and establishment in new geographical areas.
step2.part4: WHO recommends that all malaria endemic countries conduct entomological surveillance and report detection of suspected invasive species to WHO by filling and sending the
step2.whoForm: WHO form to report detection of invasive Anopheles vector species to
step2.part5: Key indicators for entomological surveillance entomological surveillance are listed in chapter 5 of the
step2.whoManual: WHO Malaria Surveillance, monitoring and evaluation: a reference manual.

step3.part1: <0>Control strategies should be informed by best practices from other countries, be adequately monitored and evaluated, and be modified where required.</0>
step3.part2: <0>Invasive vector species may adapt to their new environment by changing their traditional behaviours, including their choice of breeding habitats and resting sites, and may become insecticide resistant when exposed to vector control interventions.</0>
step3.part3: National programmes aiming to control and eliminate invasive vector species, should initially draw on best practices from countries where the species is indigenous and has been successfully controlled. However, due to the potential adaptive behavioural changes of vector species, programmes should continuously monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of the deployed vector control interventions to inform strategic adjustments when required.
step3.part4: The WHO recommends that national malaria control programs, and their executive partners, record lessons learned and send them to WHO (
step3.part5: ) in order to contribute to the development of a plan based on evidence for the control and eradication of vector and invasive species of malaria.

legend.p1: This map shows the status of compliance of local vector populations with the
legend.p1b: at different geographical sites or areas. The status has been evaluated based on data included in the Global database on insecticide resistance in malaria vectors. The map shows the status of compliance for the vector species selected on the filter pane. If no species have been filtered, the map considers all data available to evaluate the criteria.

step1.part1: <0>Monitoring insecticide resistance in malaria vectors is essential</0>
step1.part2: <0>80 of 89 malaria-endemic countries reported monitoring for insecticide resistance between 2010 and 2017. The extent and quality of data varies between countries.</0>
step1.part3: Malaria prevention is heavily reliant on core tools that target malaria mosquitoes: long-lasting insecticidal nets and indoor residual insecticide sprays. Resistance of mosquitoes to insecticides is a major concern particularly for pyrethroids as these are the only insecticide class currently approved for use on nets.
step1.part4: The WHO Global Plan for Insecticide Resistance Management in malaria vectors (GPIRM) is a call to action to maintain the effectiveness of malaria vector control. Resistance monitoring is needed to inform resistance mitigation and management strategies.

step2.part1: <0>Monitoring has found that insecticide resistance is widespread in malaria vectors</0>
step2.part2: <0>65 of 89 malaria-endemic countries have reported pyrethroid resistance in at least one local vector since 2010</0>
step2.part3: Resistance has been found in vectors from all six WHO regions and to all four classes of insecticide currently used in adult malaria vector control. Pyrethroid resistance is most commonly tested and reported.

step3.part1: <0>Recent and complete data on insecticide resistance are lacking for many countries</0>
step3.part2: <0>47 of 89 malaria-endemic countries reported data for 2017. There are relatively few data in regions other than Africa, such as South-East Asia. Monitoring often does not include all major vector species and all relevant insecticide classes.</0>
step3.part3: Up-to-date and representative data are needed for planning and implementation of vector control. Monitoring should be conducted in all malaria-endemic countries at least once per year, and should include all major vector species from the different eco-epidemiological zones. Tests should be conducted with insecticide classes that are either in use or planned for use in vector control.
step3.part4: Monitoring requirements are to be defined through a comprehensive national insecticide resistance monitoring and management plan.

step4.part1: <0>Increasing resistance underscores the urgent need for enhanced monitoring</0>
step4.part2: <0>Malaria vectors in some areas of Africa can now survive exposure to high concentrations of insecticides, indicating intensified resistance.</0>
step4.part3: Classical resistance tests measure the number of mosquitoes that survive exposure to a standard concentration of insecticide. However, intensity of resistance in survivors and the mechanisms that confer resistance are important. High intensity resistance warrants urgent action that should be guided by knowledge of the underlying resistance mechanisms.
step4.part4: WHO test procedures were recently extended to include bioassays that measure resistance intensity and metabolic mechanism involvement.

step1.part1: <0>Malaria parasites repeatedly develop resistance to antimalarial treatment</0>
step1.part2: <0>For decades, drug resistance has been one of the main obstacles in the fight against malaria.</0>
step1.part3: Continuous global monitoring and reporting of drug efficacy and parasite resistance is critical to ensure patients receive effective treatment. WHO supports national malaria control programmes to monitor antimalarial treatment efficacy and to track the genetic changes linked to drug resistance in malaria parasites.
step1.part4: The critical role of monitoring drug efficacy has been observed worldwide. Resistance has been a persistent challenge in the Greater Mekong Subregion. The region has been very active in monitoring drug efficacy.

step2.part1: <0>Routine monitoring of the efficacy of artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) is essential to ensure that patients receive effective treatment</0>
step2.part2: <0>WHO recommends that all malaria endemic countries conduct therapeutic efficacy studies at least once every two years to inform treatment policy.</0>
step2.part3: The selection of the recommended antimalarial drug is based on the medicine’s efficacy against the malaria parasite. As such, monitoring the therapeutic efficacy of antimalarial medicine is a fundamental component of malaria treatment strategies. WHO has developed a standard protocol for monitoring the treatment efficacy of antimalarial medicine.

step3.part1: <0>Studies of molecular prevention provide essential data for detecting and tracking antimalarial drug resistance</0>
step3.part2: <0>Molecular prevention for drug resistance are genetic changes in the malaria parasite found to be associated with resistance.</0>
step3.part3: Compared to efficacy studies, studies of molecular prevention have several practical advantages. For example, a large number of samples can be collected and rapidly analysed. Molecular prevention of drug resistance have been identified for different drugs, including P. falciparum resistance to chloroquine, piperaquine, mefloquine, pyrimethamine, sulfadoxine, atovaquone and artemisinins.
step3.part4: For artemisinins, several mutations in the Kelch 13 (K13)-propeller domain have been found to be associated with delayed parasite clearance. This is an evolving field as more K13 mutations are discovered and we develop a better understanding of which mutations are of greatest influence.

step4.part1: <0>Drug resistance is a challenge in both P. vivax and P. falciparum, the two most common human malaria parasite species
step4.part2: <0>Up-to-date information on drug resistance for both P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria is critical.
step4.part3: Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are the recommended treatment for the most deadly malaria parasite, P. falciparum. There are two key outcome measures for monitoring the efficacy of ACTs: (1) the proportion of treatment failures and, (2) the proportion of patients with parasites on the third day after starting treatment. An increase in the proportion of patients with parasites on day 3 is a warning sign of artemisinin resistance.
step4.part4: Chloroquine is still used in many places to treat P. vivax malaria. However, as chloroquine resistance is also developing in P. vivax parasites, some countries have shifted to ACTs for treating P. vivax malaria.
